contentrichtext.text: '''Juris Podnieks''' (December 5, 1950 – June 23, 1992) was a [[Latvia]]n [[film director]] and [[Film producer|producer]]. He graduated from the [[USSR|Soviet]] [[Gerasimov Institute of Cinematography|VGIK]] film school in 1975 after which he started working at the [[Riga Film Studio]]. He became a director in 1979. Podnieks' first film ''Cradle'' won an award at the [[Dok Leipzig]] festival. In 1981, his film ''The Brothers Kokar'' took the first prize at the [[Kiev]] Youth Festival. In the same year, his film ''Constellation of Riflemen'' won honours in the 17th All State Festival in [[Saint Petersburg|Leningrad]] and the Latvian [[Komsomol]] prize. This film gave Podnieks wide recognition within the [[Soviet Union]]. Podnieks gained international recognition with his movie ''[[Vai viegli būt jaunam?|'Is It Easy to Be Young?]]''. The film with dialogue in both [[Latvian language|Latvian]] and [[Russian language|Russian]] was an exploration of Soviet youth, in which Podnieks talked to youngsters later convicted for criminal actions. The movie broke box-office records in the Soviet Union. As the Soviet Union collapsed, Podnieks cooperated with British television to give a first-hand insight on the events in the Soviet Union. Over three years, Podnieks filmed a five-part documentary titled ''Hello, do you hear us?''. It showed civil unrest in [[Uzbekistan]], survivors of the [[1988 Spitak earthquake]] in [[Armenia]], striking workers in [[Yaroslavl]] and former residents returning to [[Chernobyl]]. The first film in the series was awarded the [[Prix Italia]]. Later, Podnieks filmed movies that focused on the rise of [[Latvian independence movement#.22Third awakening.22 .281986-1991.29|national identity]] in Latvia, [[Lithuania]] and [[Estonia]]. His ''Homeland'' was an account of [[Singing Revolution|folk festivals]] in these countries when national songs which had been banned by the Soviet regime for 50 years, were sung by massed choirs. While filming a follow-up in January 1991, Podnieks and his crew came under sniper fire during the [[The Barricades|attempted coup]] by Soviet forces in [[Riga]]. Podnieks was beaten up, his cameraman and long-time friend [[Andris Slapiņš]] was killed and [[Gvido Zvaigzne]], another collaborator and friend of Podnieks, died of injuries.<ref>[http://www.balticsworldwide.com/keep_filming.htm "Keep Filming" ''City Paper'']</ref> This was captured on video and shown as an addition to ''Homeland'' and later as an introduction for the revised version of this film. Four of his films received the [[Lielais Kristaps]] prize as the best documentary of the year. Juris Podnieks drowned on 23 June 1992 while scuba-diving in a lake in Courland. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituary-juris-podnieks-1531163.html Obituary by Juris Kaza; ''The Independent''] 4 July 1992 * [http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/arts--something-for-everyone-juris-podnieks-was-the-film-makers-film-maker-brave-tireless-driven-by-the-urge-to-bear-witness-to-the-inhumanity-of-the-soviet-system-a-channel-4-season-of-his-work-shows-that-he-was-also-extremely-gifted-1491369.html "Something For Everyone: Juris Podnieks was the film maker's film maker"; ''The Independent''] 4 July 1992 *[http://www.latfilma.lv/cm/podnieks/index.html Profile on Latfilma website] {{Authority control|VIAF=46002589}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Podnieks, Juris | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Latvian film director | DATE OF BIRTH = December 5, 1950 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = June 23, 1992 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Podnieks, Juris}} [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:1992 deaths]] [[Category:Latvian film directors]] [[Category:Soviet film directors]] [[Category:Deaths by drowning]] [[Category:Gerasimov Institute of Cinematography alumni]] {{Latvia-film-stub}}
